title: 109_hr6195
content:
The Act may be cited as the "10,000 Trained by 2011 Act." The Congress acknowledges the National Science Foundation's role in enhancing the nation's information infrastructure and the need for expertise in information processing. Basic research and curriculum development are essential for industry to leverage advanced technology. Information management is crucial for sectors like biology, with a projected 49% growth by 2010. There is a lack of a systematic plan for transitioning the workforce to the information age. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the National Science Foundation. "Information" pertains to data in sectors where the government has a significant role and a shift to digital data is occurring. "Institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RESEARCH. The Director will award grants for research on innovative approaches to improve information systems, including information studies, population informatics, translational informatics, and data security. Grants will be awarded based on merit and competition, with authorized appropriations of $3.5 million for 2008, $3.6 million for 2009, $3.7 million for 2010, and $3.8 million for 2011. Additionally, the Director will award Informatics Research Centers in consultation with other Federal agencies. The Director will award multiyear grants to institutions of higher education to establish Centers for Informatics Research in consultation with other Federal agencies. Grants will be awarded based on merit and competition for conducting cutting-edge, multidisciplinary research in innovative information approaches. The Director will award multiyear grants to institutions of higher education to establish Centers for Informatics Research. Applicants must submit an application detailing research projects, promoting collaboration among professionals from different disciplines, and contributing to increasing the number of information researchers and professionals. The Director will evaluate applications based on specified criteria. The Director will evaluate applications for Centers for Informatics Research based on criteria including innovative approaches to information, research experience, collaboration capacity, student support, and partnerships with government or other entities. The Director will convene an annual meeting of the Centers to foster collaboration and communication. Authorization of appropriations for the National Science Foundation is as follows: $4,500,000 for fiscal year 2008, $4,600,000 for fiscal year 2009, $4,700,000 for fiscal year 2010, and $4,800,000 for fiscal year 2011. SEC. 5. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION INFORMATION PROGRAMS. The Director will establish a program to award grants to institutions of higher education to improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment in information fields, provide industry experience, and use distance learning. Grants will be awarded based on merit and used to enhance information education quality, certification programs, and student recruitment. The Director will award grants to institutions of higher education to improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment, provide industry experience, and use distance learning. Activities include developing curriculum, establishing degree programs, creating research opportunities for students, acquiring equipment, providing faculty opportunities, and collaborating with other institutions. The Director will award grants to institutions of higher education to improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment, provide industry experience, and use distance learning. This includes collaborating with other academic institutions, establishing student internships, enhancing bridge programs between community colleges and universities, and any other activities determined to achieve the program's purposes. Application for funding must be submitted by the institution seeking support. Institutions of higher education must submit an application to the Director for funding, detailing research and instructional capacity, plans to build instructional capacity in information fields, and collaborations with government agencies or private industry. Institutions of higher education must submit an application to the Director for funding, detailing research and instructional capacity, plans to build instructional capacity in information fields, collaborations with government agencies or private industry, historic student enrollment and placement data, evaluation plan for the proposed program, and wide geographic and institutional diversity in grant awards. The Director will evaluate the program established under this subsection within 3 years to assess the grants' impact on increasing students pursuing degrees in information fields. Appropriations are authorized for the National Science Foundation for fiscal years 2008-2011. Grants will be provided under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992. The Director will provide grants under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992 to improve education in information fields. Authorization of appropriations for the National Science Foundation includes $7,000,000 for 2008, $7,200,000 for 2009, $7,400,000 for 2010, and $7,600,000 for 2011. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will report to Congress on efforts related to informatics, including standards harmonization and support for digitization. The report will include timetables for information standards, challenges in promulgation, ensuring usability for scientists, and actions to ensure robust and timely standards.
